data.source: Field survey (1997–1998) in 120 villages in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar; UP–Bihar LSMS (World Bank); 2001 Census of India (village-level irrigation and tubewell use)
data.wave_or_subset: 120 villages in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar; focus on Hindu villages and caste-dominated (upper-caste vs lower BAC/OBC/SC) villages; Ganga Plain region
data.notes: Village-level caste dominance treated as historically determined; minimal post-independence migration; similar infrastructure/public goods across village types; groundwater market variables include water buyer/seller status and pump ownership.

method.description: The study examines how village-level caste dominance affects household agricultural outcomes through access to groundwater markets. Using village and household data from UP–Bihar (1997–1998) and the 2001 Census, the authors compare outcomes across upper-caste and lower-caste dominated villages. They estimate OLS models of crop income and yields on a low-caste village indicator with controls, analyze water market participation, and estimate interaction models between low-caste dominance and water-buyer status. To address endogeneity of water-buyer status, they use instrumental variables with village natural water source access and village area as instruments, and conduct robustness checks for geography, groundwater quality, tenancy, credit, and segregation.
steps: Define caste dominance categories (upper-caste dominated vs lower-caste dominated: BAC/OBC/SC).
Compile village and household data from the 1997–1998 UP–Bihar survey/LSMS and village-level irrigation data from the 2001 Census.
Produce descriptive comparisons of outcomes (income, crop income per acre, yields) for lower caste households across village dominance types.
Estimate OLS regressions of agricultural income/yields on low-caste dominated village indicator with controls (education, land ownership, state/district).
Analyze groundwater market participation (pump ownership, buyers, sellers) by caste and village dominance.
Estimate interaction models between low-caste dominated village indicator and water-buyer status.
Implement IV estimation using village natural water source access and total area as instruments for water-buyer status; report first-stage strength.
Conduct robustness checks for geographic distance/area, caste segregation, environmental factors (soil/climate), tenancy, and credit relations.
Interpret the role of intra-caste trade and enforcement frictions in groundwater markets on agricultural outcomes.
method.models: OLS regressions; Instrumental Variables (2SLS) with instruments for water-buyer status
method.outcome_variable: Agricultural outcomes including crop income, crop income per acre, and agricultural yields
method.independent_variables: Low-caste dominated village indicator; water-buyer status; interaction of low-caste dominated village with water-buyer status; measures of irrigation access (e.g., private tubewell ownership/use)
method.control_variables: Education, land ownership, state/district factors; village area; caste segregation; environmental controls (soil/climate); tenancy and credit relations

results.summary: Lower caste households achieve substantially higher agricultural income and yields in villages dominated by lower castes relative to upper-caste dominated villages. The key mechanism is improved access to private groundwater irrigation and more effective trade within groundwater markets among same-caste participants. The interaction of being a water buyer and residing in a low-caste dominated village is strongly associated with higher crop income. IV estimates support a causal interpretation, and instruments are strong. Alternative explanations related to geography, groundwater quality, tenancy, credit, and segregation do not account for the differences.
